docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama signed into law Friday a defense policy bill that authorizes $611 billion for the military in 2017, lauding provisions designed to sustain momentum in countering the Islamic State group while harshly criticizing Congress's insistence on keeping open the military prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

headline.main: Obama Signs Defense Policy Bill, Objects on Guantanamo

docs.lead_paragraph: In a striking rupture with past practice, the United States allowed the U.N. Security Council on Friday to condemn Israeli settlements in the West Bank and east Jerusalem as a "flagrant violation" of international law. In doing so, the outgoing Obama administration brushed aside Donald Trump's demands that the U.S. exercise its veto and provided a climax to years of icy relations with Israel's leadership.

headline.main: UN Condemns Israeli Settlements as Obama Declines to Veto

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. President Barack Obama on Friday signed into law an annual defense policy bill, but in a lengthy statement he raised objections to parts of it, including policies blocking him from closing the detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

headline.main: Obama Signs Defense Spending Bill, Criticizes Guantanamo Policy

docs.lead_paragraph: The contention that Americans chose Trump for his racist or sexist views is wrong; many voted for him despite that.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by political analyst David Paul Kuhn disputes notion that Donald J Trump won presidency by appealing to bigotry of voters; argues most of his supporters disapproved of him morally, yet voted for him anyway because he appeared to be only champion of economically struggling Americans.

headline.main: Sorry, Liberals. Bigotry Didn’t Elect Donald Trump.

docs.lead_paragraph: Russia is not in touch with the incoming U.S. administration over Syria, but Moscow sees Donald Trump as a better partner to negotiate with than Barack Obama, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Gennady Gatilov said on Friday.
